Title.evidence: Methods: This single-centre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial included 82 patients undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass.

Trial_Design.evidence: Methods: This single-centre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial included 82 patients undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass.

Participants.evidence: Methods: This single-centre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial included 82 patients undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass.

Intervention.evidence: Oral sodium nitrate (700 mg×2) or placebo (NaCl) were administered before surgery.

Objective.evidence: We investigated if preoperative administration of inorganic nitrate could reduce troponin T release and other plasma markers of injury to the heart, liver, kidney, and brain in patients undergoing cardiac surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Troponin T release was our predefined primary endpoint and biomarkers of renal, liver, and brain injury were secondary endpoints.

Blinding.evidence: Methods: This single-centre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial included 82 patients undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Methods: This single-centre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial included 82 patients undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The 72-h release of troponin T did not differ between groups.

Harms.evidence: Blood loss was not a predefined outcome parameter, but perioperative bleeding was 18% less in nitrate-treated patients compared with controls.
